description.div: Positive health behaviors. Nutrition, physical activity, lifetime weight control, and other lifestyle factors known to improve short term and long term health risks. Practical methods for assessing, improving, and maintaining behaviors to reduce the health risks associated with both the college-age population and the general adult population.

General scientific concepts in biology, chemistry, and physics using food as a model. What food is from both chemical and nutritional perspectives, and the fate of food from when it leaves the farm to when it becomes a part of the individual. Assists students in making intelligent decisions about many food related controversial issues (e.g., food irradiation, food additives, health foods).

course.title: Foundations in Nutrition and Health Promotion

description.div: Philosophy and goals of academic programs, curricula, certifications, career opportunities and graduate programs.

Concepts, principles, and legal aspects of emergency care, cardiorespiratory emergencies, hemorrhage control, wounds, shock, heat injuries, and other medical emergencies. Considers the epidemiological factors related to accident causation.

Scientific foundation of personal health and the role of behavior in advancing individual levels of health. Principles of disease prevention in understanding the basic elements of accident prevention, substance abuse, nutrition, mental health, family planning, infection control, chronic disease prevention, sexually transmitted diseases, and organization of health services.

Theoretical and experiential analysis of the martial arts of Asia from historical, anthropological, educational, philosophical, cultural, religious, political, and sociological perspectives and their impact on contemporary Asian and global society.

notes.div: ASCI/NUTR 213 is for those students who have an interest in a career in Culinary Science, Meat Science, and/or Dietetics.

description.div: Selecting and purchasing meat for the hotel, restuarant, institutional industry, and the retail markets.

notes.div: NUTR 230 requires serving as a Wellness Advocate in the University living units to gain experience in utilizing the information learned.

description.div: The role of Wellness Advocate in the promotion of the health and wellness needs of college students. Techniques for promoting the adoption of lifestyle choices for lifelong health and well being.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing; FACS or HRTM or NUTR major.

description.div: Chemical, physical, sensory, and nutritional principles of food preparation.

course.title: Scientific Principles of Food Preparation Laboratory

description.div: Application of chemical, physical, sensory, and nutritional principles of food preparation.
Introduction to nutrient function in the body, nutrient chemistry and energy metabolism. Role of nutrients in health and disease.
Influence of normal physiological stress on nutritional requirements throughout the life cycle: pregnancy, lactation, growth, and aging.

course.title: Cultural Aspects of Food and Nutrition

description.div: The influences of culture on food and nutrition practices.
Series of minicourses devoted to specific content areas of health: A. Consumer Health N. Stress and Tension Reduction

notes.div: An accompanying seminar is included where the professional role of the teacher is discussed.

description.div: Guided participation/observation in schools/agencies offering programs for children/youth. A. Elementary (1-4 cr, max 4) Parallel EDPS 250. B. Elementary (1-4 cr, max 4) Parallel TEAC 351. I. Secondary Art (1-4 cr, max 4) J. Secondary Business Education (1-4 cr, max 4) M. Secondary Industrial Education (1-4 cr, max 4) N. Secondary Language Arts (1-4 cr, max 4) O. Secondary Marketing Education (1-4 cr, max 4) P. Secondary Mathematics (1-4 cr, max 4) Q. Middle Level (1-4 cr, max 4) R. Secondary Modern Languages (1-4 cr, max 4) V. Secondary Science (1-4 cr, max 4) W. Secondary Social Science (1-4 cr, max 4)

course.title: Special Topics in Nutritional Science and Dietetics

description.div: Topics vary.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs in major department or closely related areas and permission.

notes.div: Work supervised and evaluated by departmental faculty members.

description.div: Individual projects in research, literature review, or creative production.

Cookery principles and methods role in maintaining meat yield and quality characteristics. Cookery techniques to maximize guest satisfaction and insure foodservice and/or restaurant financial integrity. Flavor enhancement and cookery technology application in center of the plate concept development.

course.title: Food and Nutrition for Healthy Living

description.div: Role of nutrition and physical activity in healthy living. Application of current health promotion guidelines.
Prevalence and etiology of health behaviors among children and teens. Organization, development, and legal aspects of school health programming.
Overview of community nutrition. Assessment of community needs and services; policy formation; techniques for developing and delivering theory-based nutrition education.
Application of food production and purchasing principles in foodservice management.
Application of theoretical knowledge and quality assessment is provided in university or community laboratory setting.

prerequisite.div: One course in chemistry and one course in biological sciences.

description.div: Various factors that result in food illness: food allergy, natural toxins, parasites, microbial and viral food borne infections and food borne intoxications. Students will assess hazards, identify critical control points and establish monitoring and system verification procedures.
Anatomical and mechanical principles as related to human movement.

Faculty and practicing teacher supervision of practical instruction in school-based settings to ensure effective student demonstration of lesson planning, classroom management, instruction, and related decision making skills recommended by current teacher effectiveness theory related to either K-6 physical education, secondary health and physical education, or adaptive physical education. A. Elementary (2 cr) Prereq: NUTR 281; FACS 160 or EDPS 250. B. Secondary (2 cr) Prereq: NUTR 288, 321, 377, 384, 388. D. Adaptive Physical Education (1 cr) Must be taken parallel with SPED 401B. E. Community Health Practicum in a Community Setting (1 cr) Must be taken parallel with TEAC 451V.
Social, psychological, and cultural factors that influence the adoption, maintenance, and modification of health behaviors in communities.

course.title: Facts and Fiction in Fitness and Food

description.div: The application of educated judgement to accept or reject the claims made by persons who present themselves as "experts" in health and fitness. Exercise methods, exercise prescription, commonly used food and nutritional supplements, and fact versus fiction in lifetime weight control.

course.title: Physiological Foundations of Health and Disease

description.div: Topical review of current concepts of health and disease including homeostasis, bioenergetics, epidemiology, and the major chronic and infectious diseases.

course.title: Health Promotion Strategies at the Workplace

description.div: Skills and knowledge necessary to provide leadership in the designing, implementation, and evaluation of work site health promotion programs.
Using the community as a laboratory the student observes, participates in, and practices the processes of public health and health education.

Anthropological approaches to the study of nutrition. Background to nutrition science; bio-cultural aspects of obesity, fertility, lactose intolerance, and infant feeding practices; biological differences in nutritional requirements, fertility, and mortality; interpretation of nutritional deficiencies in skeletal remains; reconstructing prehistoric diets from archaeological evidence; and evaluation of relationships between dietary patterns and dental remains in fossil record.
Relationship of structure and functionality of ingredients in food systems.
Introduction to food research. Application of research techniques to selected problems.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; NUTR 441 or 445 or FDST 448; Culinology major.

description.div: Supervised individual professional Culinology research experience in product development.

prerequisite.div: BIOC 321 and 321L, or BIOC/BIOS/CHEM 431; BIOS 213 or ASCI 240.

description.div: Nutrition assessment, nutrition support, documentation of nutrition services and medical terminology.
Nutrition in the disease state. Physiological and biochemical basis of medical nutrition therapy.
Application of nutrition care process.
Application of behavior change and counseling theories to individual clients. Data assessment and interpretation, and developing goals and/or outcomes to facilitate health behavior changes.
Practical experience in developing skills in nutrition for health promotion and nutrition education.

prerequisite.div: BIOC 321 and 321L, or BIOC/BIOS/CHEM 431; BIOS 213 or ASCI 240, or parallel.

description.div: Biochemical and physiological aspects of human nutrition. Nutrient transport, storage and utilization under various metabolic states and relationships to the development of chronic diseases.

Cardiovascular, pulmonary, metabolic, pharmacologic, endocrinologic, renal, neurologic, inflammatory, and orthopedic aspects of clinical exercise physiology as they relate to exercise testing and programming.

course.title: Classroom and Outreach Experiences in Food and Nutrition

description.div: Supervised classroom or outreach experiences in educational or community settings.

Principles of cost control for foodservice. Integration of cost control and foodservice/restaurant management principles which influence financial integrity. Utilization of the computer as a tool to enhance decision making capabilities.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs science or equivalent experience; 21 years of age or older.

description.div: Origin, botany, historical and cultural significance of the grapevine and related species. Principles and practices of vineyard establishment, management and processing of grape products, importance and/or scope of grape and wine industry; global and local significance. Culinary applications, health, environmental and safety-related issues, business and industry relations and experience.
Organizational, administrative, and human relations concepts to foodservice. Utilization of computer applications in administration of a foodservice facility.
Theory and application of electrocardiography in graded exercise testing.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs biological sciences, including BIOS 213 or equivalent; NUTR 207 or BIOS 214.

notes.div: Exercise science and athletic training majors must take NUTR 207.

description.div: Effects of physical activity on the circulatory, respiratory, and other physiological processes.

course.title: Exercise Testing and Exercise Programming in Adult Fitness and Cardiac Rehabilitation

description.div: In-depth analysis and development of the techniques and knowledges prerequisite for certification in adult fitness and cardiac rehabilitation as prescribed by the American College of Sports Medicine.

course.title: Practicum in Exercise and Health Behavior Planning

description.div: Practical experience in exercise testing and analysis and planning of health and fitness programs for individuals.

course.title: Professional Preparation for Careers in Dietetics

description.div: Professional requirements in order to become a registered dietitian. Types of supervised practice experiences available and assistance in application process. Career options, professional organizations, and current issues in the dietetic profession.
Individual problems may be selected from diet therapy, animal feeding, metabolism studies, or surveys.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in major related areas; permission.

notes.div: Supervised and evaluated by departmental faculty members.

description.div: Individual projects in research, literature review, or creative production.

prerequisite.div: Admission by application; completion of all required methods courses and practica, with minimum grades of C+ (2.33) per course.

description.div: For course description, see TEAC 497. E. Elementary Physical Education (1-10 cr) K. Secondary Health (1-10 cr) U. Secondary Physical Education (1-10 cr)
Participation in an ongoing research project. Select from foods, human nutrition education, small animal, or survey research areas.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: Conduct a scholarly research project and write a University Honors Program or undergraduate thesis.

course.title: Multimedia Applications for Education and Training

description.div: Practical applications in developing and evaluating multimedia resources for students. Surveys new applications, creates and develops various instructional materials, and reviews current practice against relevant theory. Use current software packages to develop materials for various audiences.
